ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: #1 - the readings were well-chosen. I think they covered a very broad range of topics and were accessible without being boring.

The course topics were disappointing, the readings for the topics were not very good. I was overall very disappointed with this course. The instructor was unhelpful and not at all approachable. In-class discussions were supposed to be led by students but almost every time she basically commandeered the discussion and went off on at least one lengthy diatribe about something or other.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: The class presentations and NYBG field trip.

The best aspects of this course was what was learned in the field trip and the voucher-making activity. I also appreciated the wide range of topics covered. Rather than focusing too much attention on medicinal plants, for example, there was a lot of intention in the design of the course syllabus so that we would have a better understanding of the many different ways that ethnobotanical skills may be applied.
Provides a broad survey into ethnobotanical study and practice, including a workshop on plant collection. The field trip to the NYBG was amazing.
Having the opportunity to learn about ethnobotany from a practicing field scientist. Ina did offer a different take on the subject that someone who simply studied it academically.
The field trip to the NYBG was pretty neat.
The final project. The readings.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: Clarity in syllabus at the start of the semester. If there are going to be changes, it is best to discuss and obtain consensus. Inclusion of more current papers. Omit class on how to conduct scientific research, instead merge it with the introduction. Introduce topic on urban ethnobotany - community gardens. More botany!
If at all possible, I think trips or additional hands-on activities/practicums would improve this course.

Though readings were interesting, they were weakly guided, and did not contain enough substance for meaningful dialogue, particularly the non-review papers. Additionally, expectations for the culminating paper were confusing, and shifted throughout the semester. Options that seemed more open based on the syllabus turned out to be unacceptable later, and guidelines for the presentation and final paper came later still. On the whole, though performing my own research was gratifying, I see no reason why a review paper on a topic of interest should not be acceptable. It seemed ambitious for such a short-term course.
The best part of the class, a professional teacher, also presented the most difficult part. This was because sometimes I felt the expectations were not clearly communicated.

All of it can be improved - the powerpoint lectures were not at all helpful. The 'discussion' part of class could have been much improved. The instructor did not do a good job of fostering actual discussion, rather the instructor insisted on responding to every comment made by the students and was not very open or welcoming to comments that differed from what she had already pre-determined was a 'correct' answer or the 'correct' way of looking at an issue.
It would have been nice to cover seminal works of ethnobotany and more theory. incorporation of movies and films would have been nice. Classes often dragged on a bit.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: I appreciate that this course provides practical skills, not just a theoretical base. In that way it was a good mix.
It doesn't.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: To learn more about the field! This was a success.
I thought it would be an interesting course with different subject matter from most of the ones I've taken at F&ES so far.
Interested in the relationship between humans and nature

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Urban ethnobotany, medicinal plants

Yes, with respect to vouchers I have a much better understanding of the methods. I still felt somewhat confused about the material covering quantitative data analysis. I think I might have learned it better if given an assignment to do at home with instructions, rather than try to follow at the pace of other students.

I gained valuable experience conducting interview-based research in this class, which was a new frontier for me. I gained a lot of knowledge about ethnobotany as a discipline, but less than I would have thought about plant groups and general trends in their usage.

No. I don't feel I learned much at all. The topics covered were very superficial. I don't feel like it was an F&ES-caliber course. Importantly, the requirements for the final project were entirely different from what was stated on the syllabus. The syllabus said: "Examples of projects can include (but are not limited to) a research funding proposal about an ethnobiological subject, a review paper that includes a thorough ethnobiological literature review of a species (see the journal Economic Botany for examples), an edited video or photo essay of any ethnobiological relevant topic, a herbarium of New Haven weedy plant species of medicinal or nutritional value." In the middle of the semester this somehow turned into everybody being required to produce an academic research paper with original research for final projects. This was entirely misleading and completely unfair to all of the students.

Mostly. I gained good knowledge of what ethnobotany is all about, and got to experience the methodologies discussed in class through the final project. Didn't get a chance to learn many of the botanical families (not enough time allocated)

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Ask yourself: "Do I want to learn about the ins and outs of ethnobotany? Will it make a difference for my career? If yes, take the class. If you want an introduction, I'd say consider whether it is worth it for you to have this background.
Don't bother. You can get much more out of any other course at F&ES and the instructor is difficult to work with.
Good elective course. You won't leave an expert in ethnobotany, but you'll have a better understanding of the subject.
